subj-group.subject: Symposium on Forecasting the State of the Public Finances

title-group.article-title: Forecasting the Public Finances in the Treasury

abstract.p: This article describes the methods used by the Treasury and other government departments for making forecasts of the public finances. A highly detailed approach is required because of the Treasury's budgetary role, but the aggregated results are subjected to careful 'top-down' checks. Forecasts have a necessary role in fiscal policy. But they are subject to large margins of error, and should be presented and used with caution.

p.mixed-citation: All the published forecasts up to 1993 are collected together in HM Treasury (1993).

For a recent description of the Treasury model, see Chan, Savage and Whittaker (1995). A full description and listing of all the equations is given in the HM Treasury Macroeconomic Model Documentation', updated annually and available from the Treasury.

It has proved very difficult in recent years to model and forecast VAT receipts, partly because of the expansion of tax planning and avoidance and a worsening of traders' compliance. These problems are discussed in HM Treasury (1997a).
Forecasting errors and policy mistakes during that period are discussed in HM Treasury (1997b).
See the more rigorous analysis on a longer dataset in Melliss ( 1996).
